comments.commentBody:
The people who wrote the law claimed that they didn't intend states that didn't set up exchanges not to get exchanges, so Davey here is misrepresenting the truth. He's probably talking about a quote from Jon Gruber, a non-legislator, non-drafter of the bill who has worked as a consultant on the PPACA. He said: "What’s important to remember politically about this is if you're a state and you don’t set up an exchange, that means your citizens don't get their tax credits—but your citizens still pay the taxes that support this bill." Even in that context, he may have had it confused with the Medicaid expansion.

Here's a link: http://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2014/07/did-congress-actually-inte...

The efforts of "Parents Across America--Florida" and others has led to this change in Palm Beach County and now other counties are following. This movement started in Texas where some tests have been eliminated.
This is the power of parents!! And it must continue to grow because moms are going to hold politicians responsible (not teachers) for this mess!!
You lifespan graphs link has nothing to do with a one year old law. It's an easy guess to say obesity and cigarette smoking put, for instance, Mississippi last.

This isn't an issue of whether the ACA is good policy, the issue is whether the administration has implemented it legally. They haven't, according to the architect of the bill and most attorneys who have reviewed it.

Certainly the drastic differences in lifespans between red and blue states has to do with more than just the policy differences, but given how neatly the states split along red/blue lines in that regard, it is hard to say that it has nothing to do with policy- http://politicsthatwork.com/graphs/life-expectancy-by-state

Interesting side note- Utah implemented ACA-like health insurance exchanges years ago. Seems to me that we have a pretty clear idea of what approaches to healthcare work better than others.

Jundallah is al Qaeda-affiliated terrorist group, that conducts its terrorist activities in the interests of our intelligence community possibly? I mean, c'mon! Let's remember what Edward Snowden has revealed about the spying activities of American government and CIA. Some data even included you and me and our private communications.

But why is what you've done to justify your POV of the Muslim world any different -- or any better -- than what Mr. McHale did? Other than that, likely, you come from more upscale, and academically-credentialled surroundings than the obviously Blue Collar Mr McHale?

You both sampled tiny bits of evidence, and he is the one who at least travelled to that world, met people there, and put himself at personal risk.

He believes a more conventional wisdom among his set: that Middle Eastern terrorists are motivated by a hateful, paranoid and ultimately irrational view of the world -- and that the only thing we can do is fight them off.

You believe a more conventional wisdom among your set: that terrorists are motivated by bad things done by the West...especially Western leaders who are Republicans -- and of course especially Israel(!), and that the only route forward is to listen to their discontents and seek accommodation with them.

What makes you so such you are the one who's right?
Are you suggesting that the US Congress would support someone else's agenda instead of US?
Did you read the article? The Port Authority cop was a member of the FBI Joint Terrorist Task Force. Are you familiar with the task force concept and how the FBI JTTF operates? Obviously not.

You didn't read the article and clearly have no concept of how the FBI Task Force work or operates. He was a member of the FBI Task Force.

In 1993, NYPD cops solved the first WTC bombing by finding the C-VIN of the bomb carrying vehicle!

It is very easy to call him a doughnut cop from your breakfast table on a Sunday morning. You know nothing about his career and what he has accomplished.

No, your facts are wrong. It was the Holland Tunnel, not the Lincoln Tunnel. The Pulaski Skyway feeds directly into the Holland Tunnel.

And besides, the Lincoln Tunnel is not 12 miles away from the Skyway!

You are wrong on both points!

Your comment is a breath of fresh air. Those here who support the heinous Iranian regime are supporting radical Islamists who are on the verge of attaining nuclear weapons.
There is no greater threat to peace and stability than the Iranian regime.

Well, then you have to take responsibility for running a country of 60 million people for awhile. That's much larger than Iraq, and we had more than enough trouble there.

I suspect you might be kidding here.

On the other hand, it could be said that the American/Israeli "intelligence" complex is the largest, most powerful terrorist organization in the world. What was the South Lebanon Army? What was Avriham Nir doing in Nicragua? Who helped Bashir Gemayal massacre Palestinians at Sabra and Shatilla? And who has been cooperating to assassinate nuclear scientist civilians in Iran? Who helped Saddam Hussein obtain the infrastructure to manufacture chemical munitions?

And this complex has for decades possessed nuclear weapons. Awaken to the nightmare.

Tom McHale was no rogue, he did his job and did it well. Apparently better than the FBI and CIA were doing theirs. Human intelligence is the currency of the IC and developing sources is necessary. Informants are by their very nature less than savory characters, but necessary none the less.
Tom McHale gave a measure of devotion to protecting this nation that few could even imagine. The comments choosing to denigrate him, his actions and the PAPD are ridiculous; he was a great police officer and an outstanding detective. He was the subject matter expert for the FBI and CIA.
McHale demonstrated a tenacity seen in few; his blunt spoken manner is that of a person who gets results. To insinuate that the United States government was unaware of his activities and allowed him to act on his own is ridiculous.
Risen and Apuzzo are the proxies here, doing the bidding of others with this personal attack. That McHale’s intelligence reports were so circulated throughout the IC is testament to the usefulness of the sources he cultivated. The work of the IC is murky; the defense of a nation requires such extraordinary, lawful measures to be successful.
McHale's actions are commendable. We were attacked, on September 11, he knows this all too intimately. We are fortunate to have men like him to fight the good fight.
I am kind of amazed by all the arm chair quarterbacks snearing at McHale.   A huge part of real police work involves luck and the ability to exploit that luck.  McHale obviously had that skill.

Re: Marvinsky, " I haven't noticed Iran invading anyone, for a few dozen centuries anyway."

You should read about Nadir Shah who invaded Mughal Empire Capital Delhi, not once, but twice, and took its entire treasury with him to Persia. The stolen treasury is still there in the vaults of Bank Melli Iran in Tehran including the Peacock throne.
After reading this article I would not wager ten dollar that dots presented are connected beyond a reasonable doubt. Another acorn dropped into the squirrel cage.
a succession of NIEs has stated that Iran doesn't have an ongoing nuclear weapons program. Sunni extremists have attacked the U.S., but iran hasn't.

I don't have a lot of faith in five of the Supreme Court justices. However I suspect, given how flimsy this challenge seems to be, that the Court is accepting it because different courts have ruled differently on the case. They'll probably rule in favor of the subsidies to prevent lower courts from interfering with them.

Someone else (under the brief name B) posted this comment, which seems to address this:
Professor, what you said is true but it is not only a matter of a "typo." You are referring to Section 1311 of PPACA, which repeatedly uses "the State" when describing all requirements of the law to be implemented through exchanges.
However, Section 1321 of PPACA states specifically that should any State opt to not establish and operate an exchange the federal government (Secretary of HHS) shall operate an exchange on behalf of such a State and shall implement all requirements of the law. The wording is very clear. "The Secretary (HHS) shall ... establish and operate such Exchange within the State and the Secretary shall take such actions as are necessary to implement other requirements."

Socrates, whether or not the court has interpreted the Second Amendment correctly has zero to do with how it will, and should, interpret the Affordable Care Act.  Frankly, and with all due respect, it's a diversion. I actually agree that the Roberts court has been too political and result-oriented, especially in the Citizens United and Hobby Lobby decisions, which the court got wrong. As for the Second Amendment, I haven't looked closely at the court's decisions in this area so cannot comment extensively (except that from what I have heard, even Antonin Scalia believes that significant gun control measures are allowed under the constitution). In any event, whether or not the court has gotten Second Amendment analysis right, I stand by my position that the court probably will not stretch "Established by the State" to mean "Established by the State or Federal Government." That's a big stretch, and would require a lot of contextual interpretation to get to that this court (even the liberal justices) probably will not undertake. Ultimately, the statutory language has to count for something.

Not just the 2nd amend to allow guns for all is warped. The court and state govts define the b. of rights however they want.
They ignore or distort the 1st amend free speech, and establishment of religion, plus unreasonable searches, excessive fines and bail and cruel, unusual punishment, equal protection and due process, and voting rights. We see this in the news every day.

Nocera just wrote about former ACLU pres agreeing with Citizens United, based on free speech for big money. He thinks to limit it would be worse than allowing it. By implication, to not auction off our elections to the highest bidder would be a dictatorship. How does one combat such surreal reasoning?

I think it's important to keep in mind the underlying wording in the Affordable Care Act, which is that subsidies are available in "an Exchange Established by the State." This is the passage that the Supreme Court will be asked to interpret, yet the passage itself was omitted from Mr. Krugman's article.

I am a lawyer, and I think it will be difficult for the Supreme Court (even the liberal justices) to reach the conclusion that "Established by the State" means "Established by the State or Federal Government." Therefore, it is very possible that the court will take the view that, given this passage, the subsidies are unavailable in states that rely on the federal exchange.

I wish this weren't the case, because I support the ACA and, more generally, support expanded access to health care. However, the decision might not come down to politics, but to legal reasoning.

Of course, it was Roberts who cast the deciding vote that ruled that the individual mandate was essentially a tax, in accordance with government authority, and therefore, a reasonable provision of the law. That's saved the law so far. The ACH would be cruel and unworkable if people who cannot afford insurance without assistance are forced by the mandate to buy what they cannot afford. In fact, it would be monstrous. I guess we'll see if five of the Supremes can be monsters.

God, I used to love to hear those guys do "James Connolly" and "Desperate" and "Fanatic Heart" at Paddy Reilly's in the early 90's!  What an impish spirit Larry always had, incarnating both the Irish poet and the rebel.  Beautiful.

I saw them a handful of times between '94 and '01, then they kind of drifted out of my consciousness as I picked up several new bands to follow and ended up living in places where they didn't play.  Luckily I got one last chance to see them, 2 weeks ago in Portland.  It was bittersweet, realizing that this is still a great band playing unique songs that I love but that I'll never see them again.
Great show in Central Park.

I've seen Black 47 perform many times over the past 20 years in many different venues.  They've always stayed true to their roots and true to their ideals.  I'll miss seeing Larry and the boys perform live but I thank them for all the great music over the years and wish them the best going forward.

I first saw them back in 1996, on a dark and stormy night in Providence, RI--the now-infamous gig at the Strand that has since been immortalized in song. My newly-minted husband suggested we head out to the show, despite the lousy weather--he thought I might like what I heard. It was indeed a pleasure to meet them that night, and I did like what I heard, very much.

Their music has brought so much joy into our lives over the last 18 years. It has made us think, AND dance--sometimes all at once! They are the soundtrack to our NY, and to our marriage (and we're not even Irish!). We'll be there on Saturday, to raise our fists, and our glasses, one last time. But mostly, we'll be there to thank them, for all they've given to their fans, and to music, over the years. We will miss them so very much, and wish them each and all a great next chapter!
